prompts: I need help starting a hard conversation with my manager about resetting workload because I'm burning out. Context: I'm a mid-level product manager at a mid-size tech company, remote. For 6 months I've been given 'urgent' weekend tasks; my performance is strong, but I'm exhausted. My manager is kind but avoids conflict. I want to propose: no ad-hoc work after 6pm, a rotated weekend on-call, and pushing two projects to next quarter. I'm worried I'll sound uncommitted. Can you give me (a) a 60-90 second opening for a 15-minute 1:1, (b) one sentence that ties boundaries to better outcomes, and (c) a concise response if they say 'the business needs it now'?

How can I bring up to my roommate that their partner is over too much without starting a fight? Details: we split rent 50/50 on a 2BR; lease lists only us. For 2 months their partner has stayed 5-6 nights/week, uses utilities, and leaves dishes. I'm fine with occasional stays, but I'd like either a limit (max 2 nights/week) or a rent/utilities adjustment. Please draft a short text to ask for a sit-down, plus 3 phrases I can use in the conversation to keep it calm and specific.

Can you draft a short text I can send to my girlfriend, Maya, to apologize and repair after a fight last night? Context: we argued about me canceling dinner with her parents. I got defensive, raised my voice, and said she was 'making a big deal out of nothing.' I realize I didn't communicate and made her feel dismissed. I want to take responsibility, validate her feelings, and suggest we take a walk after work to talk. Keep it warm but not clingy, avoid love-bombing, 80–120 words max, and include a clear 'I' statement and one specific action I'll do differently next time.

Help me write a brief Slack DM to my teammate Alex after I undercut him in today's standup by correcting him in front of everyone. I want to apologize without making him do emotional labor, acknowledge the impact (embarrassing him, taking over), and offer a concrete repair (follow-up message to the team owning my mistake + ask how he'd like to proceed next time). Keep it professional, 4–6 sentences, and end by proposing a quick 10-minute chat if he's open.

My manager often DMs me on Slack late at night because our team is spread across time zones. I want to set a clear but friendly boundary that I won’t be available after 6 pm unless it’s a true emergency, and that I’ll respond the next business day. Can you draft a concise message I can send to my manager to set this expectation?

My mom keeps dropping by my apartment without texting first. I love seeing her, but it disrupts my schedule. Can you help me write a short, kind text that asks for at least 24 hours’ notice and suggests weekend afternoons as a good time to visit?

Whenever my boyfriend, Alex, likes or comments on other women’s Instagram photos, I get this stab of jealousy and start spiraling even though he hasn’t broken any boundaries we agreed on. I don’t want to be controlling, but I also want to feel respected. Can you give me a few quick tips for managing the jealousy in the moment, and a short, non-accusatory script I can use to open a calm conversation with him about social media boundaries?

I’m feeling jealous of a coworker who just got promoted to a role I wanted. I’m happy for her but also bitter and comparing myself. Can you outline a simple plan to turn this into growth: 4–5 practical steps I can take over the next month, one reframe to repeat when the jealousy hits, and a brief way to congratulate her without sounding fake?

Our startup BrightLedger had a security incident on Nov 30 that exposed names and emails for about 2% of users; no passwords or financial data were involved. We patched the vulnerability, rotated all tokens, engaged an external security firm, and are offering 12 months of credit monitoring. Please draft a 150–200 word customer email that acknowledges the breach, apologizes without deflecting, briefly explains what happened, outlines what we’ve done, and gives clear next steps plus contact info. Tone: transparent, accountable, and reassuring. Include incident reference BL-2025-1130 and contact security@brightledger.com.

I broke my boyfriend’s trust by reading his messages without permission, and he found out. Can you give me a simple 4-week plan with 5–7 specific actions to rebuild trust (boundaries, transparency, check-ins, etc.) and a short 3–4 sentence apology text I can send today? Please keep it practical and not overly dramatic.

My partner and I are 9 months into a long-distance relationship (NYC to London, 5-hour time difference). We both work full-time, and our communication has started to feel routine—mostly logistics and quick check-ins. Could you suggest practical ways to make our conversations feel more connected and fun during the week, and ideas for 'virtual dates' that don't require a lot of prep?

I'm moving abroad for grad school for 18 months while my boyfriend stays in California. We trust each other but I'm anxious about drifting apart. What habits and boundaries should we set now (communication cadence, conflict resolution, visits, budget) to keep the relationship strong without feeling overwhelmed?

I need help balancing work, family, fitness, and an online course without burning out. Context: I work 9–5 Mon–Fri with a 40-minute commute each way. Dinner/bedtime with kids is 6–8 pm and I want to protect that. I’d like to get to the gym 3 times a week for 45 minutes, and complete 4 hours/week of an online certification. Saturdays 9–11 am are taken by my kid’s soccer. Please suggest (a) a simple weekly template with time blocks (morning/lunch/evening) showing where each priority fits, and (b) 3 concise tips to protect study time. Keep it brief.

I have 3 hours of focused time today and need help prioritizing. Here are my tasks:
- Draft client proposal (2h): due tomorrow 5 pm, high revenue impact.
- Expense report (30m): overdue by 2 days; finance is pinging me.
- Fix medium-severity product bug (1.5h): due in 3 days.
- Prepare slides for internal update (1h): meeting next week; low impact.
- Clear 25 emails (1h): mix of FYIs and a few minor approvals.
- Optional vendor call (30m): could unlock a small discount; can reschedule this week.
Given my energy is best in the morning (which is now), tell me what to do in the 3 hours today, what to schedule later this week (with rough timing), and what to defer or delegate. Please keep the reasoning brief.

I'm meeting my girlfriend's parents for the first time this Saturday at their place for a home-cooked dinner. Her dad is pretty traditional, her mom is vegetarian; I'm an introvert and have a small forearm tattoo that might show. What should I wear, bring as a host gift, and talk about/avoid to make a good first impression? Please keep it to a few practical tips.

Any quick advice for meeting my boyfriend's Indian parents during Diwali at their home? I want to be respectful—how should I greet them, what small gift is appropriate, any dress code or dietary dos/don'ts, and what are safe conversation topics? A short checklist is perfect.

My boyfriend (30) and I (28) are thinking about moving in together after 10 months. We both have stable jobs, each earn around $75k, and currently pay separate rents ($1,500 me, $1,300 him). We both WFH 2–3 days a week. I like quiet evenings; he hosts friends for game nights once or twice a month. His lease ends in July; mine ends in October, so timing is a factor. Could you give us a short checklist of the key conversations we should have before deciding (money, chores, alone time, guests, conflict resolution), a simple fair way to split rent/utilities, and 3 signs we should wait a bit longer?

I’m considering moving in with a close friend to cut costs for the next year. We’re looking at a 2BR, 1 bath. I’m an early sleeper with a 6am shift; he’s a night-owl gamer. He has a small dog; I don’t have pets. What should we agree on upfront to make this work? Please suggest a concise set of ground rules (quiet hours, chores, guests/overnights, shared items, pet responsibilities, bills/late payments, cleaning standards), and whether it’s smart to try a 30-day trial period first and how to structure it.

We’re three roommates—Alex (works 9–5 weekdays, gym Tue/Thu 6–7:30 pm), Bri (barista shifts early mornings Wed–Sun, free Mondays), and Chen (grad student, classes Mon/Wed 2–6 pm, lab Fri evenings). Weekly chores: trash/recycling (Mon & Thu nights), dishes (daily), sweep/vacuum (once), bathroom clean (once), kitchen deep clean (once). Preferences/constraints: Alex hates bathroom but is fine with trash; Bri can’t do late Thu; Chen is allergic to bleach (can’t do bathroom chemicals). Please propose a simple 4‑week rotating schedule that balances effort and honors constraints, and list 3 fairness rules (e.g., rotation, swaps, make-up tasks). Keep it concise.

We’re a family of four: two adults, kids ages 12 and 9. Weekly chores: laundry (2 loads), dinner cleanup (6 nights), pet care (morning & evening), trash/recycling (Wed night), yard tidy (Sat), bathroom wipe-down (twice). Time limits: kids ~30 min/day; adults ~45 min/day. Preferences: 12-year-old likes pet care; 9-year-old dislikes trash; adults are flexible. Please make a simple one-week chore chart that’s fair by time/effort and include a basic $10/week allowance split tied to completed chores.

My partner and I are moving in together next month. I make $72k, he makes $55k, I have $180/mo in student loans, and our rent will be $2,000 plus about $200 utilities. Can you outline a 30-minute conversation plan to decide how to split rent/bills fairly (proportional vs. 50/50), set a small joint emergency fund target, and agree on transparency (what we share vs. keep private)? Please include 5–7 bullet talking points and a few sample phrases to keep it calm and collaborative.

We’re a married couple wanting a monthly 45-minute money check-in with a joint account for shared bills and separate accounts for personal spending. Combined after-tax income: $7,200/month. Typical shared expenses: rent $1,650, utilities/internet $230, groceries $600, transport $300. Please propose: (1) a simple agenda, (2) a basic budget split (what goes joint vs. personal), and (3) two ground rules for purchases over $200 and a conflict de-escalation script for when we disagree about discretionary spending.

I just realized our love languages don’t match: I naturally show love through Acts of Service, but my partner really responds to Words of Affirmation. Can you give me three specific, sincere things I can say or send this week that would hit her language, and three simple ways to describe what Acts of Service looks like for me without sounding demanding?

Can you help me infer my love language from these reactions? I feel most loved when my partner sits with me device-free for an evening and when they help me finish a chore I’ve been dreading. Compliments are nice but don’t really stick, surprise gifts feel thoughtful but not essential, and frequent hugs are pleasant but not what I crave first. Which love language(s) do I likely prioritize, and what’s a short, clear way I can tell my spouse about it?

Can you design a low-key, meaningful first date in Seattle for this Saturday, 3-6 pm, assuming light rain? She’s an introvert who loves cozy bookstores, tea, and poems; dislikes loud bars and spicy food. Budget: up to $80. We’ll be taking public transit and need wheelchair-friendly spots. Please suggest: a simple 2-stop itinerary (with addresses and approximate timing), one shared activity that sparks conversation, 3 gentle conversation starters, and a quick rain-safe backup in case the first stop is packed.

Help me plan a meaningful sunrise beach date in San Diego this Sunday from 6:30-8:00 am for my partner who loves dogs and film photography. Budget under $50. We’ll bring our dog. I’d like: a simple schedule with a specific beach recommendation and parking tip, a small shared ritual (e.g., writing intentions in the sand), a short photo prompt list (5 shots max), and a minimal picnic menu I can prep the night before. Also include one contingency idea if marine layer is heavy.

Married 9 years, two kids under 6, and we’re usually wiped by 9 pm. We miss feeling flirty and connected but don’t have energy for elaborate dates. Can you give us 5 simple, screen-free micro-dates we can do at home in 20–30 minutes, plus 5 playful conversation starters that aren’t about work or kids? Keep ideas under a $15 budget.

Long-distance couple (NYC–London), together 3 years. Our weeknights overlap about 25 minutes and are often audio-only. We value words of affirmation and quality time, but our routine feels stale. Please suggest 4 recurring rituals and 3 fun prompts/games to keep things romantic without video or spending money.

At my new job, several coworkers keep asking to follow my Instagram and TikTok. I want to keep my personal accounts separate from work and only connect on LinkedIn. Can you give me 4 concise, polite responses I can use in DMs or in person to set that boundary, and one sentence I can add to my bio to signal this?

My parents and in-laws keep posting photos of our toddler publicly on Facebook and Instagram without asking. We’d like a simple policy: ask before posting, no last name, no location tags, and private accounts only. Please draft a friendly group text that sets these boundaries, plus 3 quick tips I can give them on adjusting privacy settings.

I’ve been seeing someone for about 2 months. We text daily, but sometimes she takes 3–6 hours to reply and I get anxious. What’s considerate etiquette around response times and is it okay to double-text? Could you give me a few do’s/don’ts and a short example message to set expectations without sounding clingy?

My boyfriend and I had a minor argument last night, and we’re both busy today. Should we try to clear the air over text or wait to talk in person? If texting makes sense, what are some etiquette tips (message length, tone, emojis), and can you give me a brief example opener that helps de-escalate?

A VC just sent me a pre-seed term sheet with a 30-day exclusivity/no-shop. I have two other firms mid-conversation and a product demo scheduled next week. I don’t want to burn bridges, but I also don’t want to stall momentum. Can you give me concise talking points for a call to narrow the clause (shorter window, carve-outs for existing conversations, mutual fast timelines), plus a short alternative clause I can propose in email?

I run a hardware startup (industrial IoT sensors). A distributor in Germany wants 2-year exclusive rights in DACH if they hit €1M/year in purchases. I’d like to counter with performance-based exclusivity (ramp and quarterly checkpoints), carve-outs for direct web sales and two named global accounts, and a cure/termination mechanism. Can you draft a brief counterproposal email and bullet the key terms to include?

New relationship, long-distance: We live 500 miles apart and both work full-time. Help me define realistic expectations for communication (frequency/response times), visits (how often/who travels), money (splitting travel costs), and exclusivity. Please provide: (1) a concise checklist of points to align on, and (2) a 3–4 sentence message I can send to start the conversation.

My partner and I are moving in together after 2 years. Could you outline balanced expectations for living together—chores, quiet hours, personal space, hosting guests, finances, and how we handle disagreements? Keep it to bullet points plus a brief 'house agreement' paragraph I can propose.

My ex and I broke up 6 weeks ago. They keep sending late-night texts like “I miss us” and asking to meet. I don’t want to rekindle anything and I’d like to set a clear boundary without being harsh. Can you help me draft a 2–3 sentence reply that is firm, kind, and leaves no room for debate? For context: no kids or shared property; breakup was amicable but I felt emotionally drained.

I’m co-parenting with my ex. We have a 5-year-old and our schedule is Mon–Wed with me, Thu–Sun with them. Lately they’ve been returning our child 30–45 minutes late without telling me, which messes up my work. Please write a short, non-confrontational message that: (a) asks them to notify me if they’re running late, (b) proposes a 15-minute grace period, and (c) confirms the plan going forward.

My partner (they/them) is under intense stress prepping for a certification exam next week. They've been irritable and skipping meals, and when I ask how to help they say 'I'm fine.' I want to be supportive without nagging. Could you suggest 6 short, compassionate things I can say tonight, and 4 low-effort acts of support I could offer this week that respect their space?

My wife just had a rough month at work (layoffs, longer hours) and she's exhausted and teary. We have two kids, and I work nights, so our time overlaps are short. I tend to jump into problem-solving, which she hates. Can you help me: a) write a 2–3 sentence text I can send during her break to show support, and b) list three questions I can ask later that invite her to vent without me taking over?

I'm a project manager in London. One of my team members, Sara, avoids handshakes with men for religious reasons; she smiles and places her hand over her heart. Next week we'll meet a new client who is very traditional about handshakes. Can you suggest a brief, respectful way for me to introduce Sara so it heads off any awkwardness, plus one or two backup lines I can use if the client offers his hand? Keep it concise.

I need to post a short note in our team Slack about Ramadan. We’re a mixed team (US-based, 18 people; two Muslim colleagues will be fasting). I want to acknowledge the month, offer flexible scheduling around sunsets, and suggest non-food alternatives for celebrations, without singling anyone out. Please draft 2–3 sentences I can paste.

I’m a barista and a customer started yelling that their latte was made wrong during the morning rush. How can I de-escalate this quickly without holding up the line? Please give a concise, step-by-step approach and 3 example phrases I can say, plus one thing I should avoid saying.

My roommate and I got into a heated argument about dishes—voices raised and blame flying. What practical de-escalation techniques can I use in the moment to cool things down and reset the conversation? Please give a short checklist and a 2–3 sentence script to reopen the talk after we take a 10-minute break.

Help us decide whether to relocate from Cleveland to Seattle for my wife’s promotion. Context: I'm 33 (remote software engineer, $145k), she's 34 (marketing manager, offer is $175k with better growth). Current combined income $265k in Cleveland; Seattle would be ~\$320k. Cost of living: our Cleveland rent is \$1,700; comparable Seattle rent would be ~\$3,400. We want to start trying for a baby in a year. Both our families live within 30 minutes of Cleveland and could help with childcare; in Seattle we know two friends but no family. We like outdoor activities and urban amenities, but I worry about being far from our parents as they age. Timeline to decide: 3 weeks. Please give us a concise decision framework: the 4 most important factors to weigh, 4 quick questions we should ask each other, and a simple rule-of-thumb to make a go/no-go call.

Newly married, we’re torn on how to handle money together. Details: I make \$82k, my spouse makes \$105k. Debts: I have \$12k student loans at 4%, they have a \$5k car loan at 2.9%. Savings: \$28k combined. Goals: buy a home in ~18 months, take one international trip a year, and keep some personal spending freedom. I'm frugal; they're more spontaneous, and we’ve had a few arguments about ‘fairness’ when splitting dinners and gifts. Could you suggest 3 practical models for our finances (e.g., fully joint, proportional split with separate fun money, etc.), give 1–2 pros/cons for each, and outline a brief agenda for a 30‑minute conversation to pick one?

Our 10th wedding anniversary is next month. My wife (34) loves trail running, baking sourdough, and small indie concerts. She’s minimalist, doesn’t wear much jewelry, and we live in a small Seattle apartment. I’d like meaningful, clutter-light ideas that nod to the traditional tin/aluminum theme if possible. Budget up to $150. Please suggest 6 gift ideas (mix of experience and physical), each with 1-2 sentences on why it fits, and include one thoughtful DIY option. No subscriptions or spa certificates.

I’m planning a low-key 30th anniversary day for my parents in Chicago in late May. Dad loves jazz; Mom loves gardens and tea. Budget is about $200 total. Two kids (8 and 11) will join, so it needs to be family-friendly. Can you suggest 4 cohesive celebration options (daytime activity + simple dinner idea + small gift), each with rough costs, and then write a short 2-3 sentence heartfelt message for their card?

How can I ask my boyfriend to give me more space during the week without making it sound like I’m pulling away? We currently text all day and see each other 5 nights a week; I’d like to scale that back to 2–3 nights and less frequent texting so I can focus on grad school and recharge. Please give me a short, empathetic script I can say, plus 3 quick tips for keeping the connection strong while we try this.

My parents live close by and often drop in without warning. I love them, but I need more independence with my new baby and our routines. Could you write a friendly text I can send setting a ‘please call before visiting’ boundary and suggest a simple visiting schedule we can offer (e.g., two evenings per week)? Keep it warm but firm.

I love my wife, but our sex drives are different. She’d like intimacy multiple times a week, and my interest is lower right now due to stress and meds. I don’t want her to feel unwanted, and I need my boundaries respected. Could you suggest a short conversation script I can use to explain this kindly and propose alternatives (like more non-sex touch and planned date nights) so we both feel connected?

How can I tell my boyfriend that I need more emotional closeness than he does—like more frequent check-ins and cuddling—without it sounding like a demand? Please give me 3 practical steps and a brief example message to start the conversation, and a respectful way to ask about his needs too.

I’m struggling with jealousy at work. A peer I started with just got promoted and I didn’t, and now I catch myself nitpicking their decisions and avoiding their messages. I don’t want to be that person. Can you give me a few practical steps to manage the jealousy, a short script to congratulate them that sounds genuine, and one or two ways to refocus on my own growth without obsessively comparing?

How do I handle jealousy toward a classmate who always scores highest and gets called on by the professor? I’m starting to feel discouraged and snippy around them, which I don’t like. Can you suggest a few strategies to turn this into motivation, a quick self-talk phrase to use after grades come out, and one boundary to reduce unhelpful comparison (e.g., around study groups or social media)?

My ex and I share 50/50 custody of our 7-year-old. Lately they’ve been returning our child late and not looping me in on school events. I want to keep things cooperative. Can you draft 2–3 short, neutral text messages that (1) acknowledge we’re both busy, (2) ask to stick to pickup/drop-off times, and (3) suggest using a shared calendar for school updates?

I’m a new stepmom to two kids (9 and 12). My partner is pretty permissive, and I’m more structure-oriented. We keep clashing over bedtime and chores. What are three practical steps we can try this month to get aligned without me overstepping, and could you include a brief script I can use to start that conversation with my partner?

My brother and I disagree about climate policy—he’s skeptical of government regulation, and I support stronger action. I want to text him to suggest we talk without arguing. Can you draft a short, friendly message (4–6 sentences) that sets respectful ground rules, focuses on shared values (like caring about our town’s economy and environment), and avoids trying to persuade him?

I’m facilitating a neighborhood meeting where people hold very different views on immigration. Please give me a brief, neutral summary of the main concerns and values typically expressed by those favoring more restrictive policies and those supporting more open policies, and then list 5 open-ended, non-leading questions I can use to keep the conversation constructive.

I lead a 5-person product team. One teammate, Dan, consistently picks the smallest tickets and skips or shows up late to code reviews, which pushes more complex work onto others. I want to address this without blame. Can you draft: (1) a brief 1:1 script to clarify expectations and explore blockers, and (2) a 3–4 sentence note I can say in the next standup to reset norms on equitable workload and review participation?

I live with two roommates, Alex and Priya. I’ve been doing most of the dishes and taking out the trash lately, and it feels unbalanced. Please write a short, friendly group chat message that: mentions the pattern without accusing, proposes a simple rotating chore schedule (dishes, trash, floors), and asks for their input on what’s fair.

Help me write a short, playful-but-sincere Tinder bio. About me: 31M software engineer in Austin; into trail running, live music, cooking spicy food; rescue dog named Pico; values: kindness and curiosity; looking for a long-term relationship; 5'10". Avoid clichés and emojis. Please give me 2 options, each under 150 characters.

I matched with someone on Hinge and need a reply. Her profile: avid rock climber, horror-movie fan, coffee snob, vegetarian; pics with a golden retriever (not sure if it’s hers). She opened with: "Your dog Pico is adorable! What’s his favorite park?" I’m 31M in Austin. Suggest 3 flirty-but-respectful replies that answer her question, show shared interests, and end with a light question or invite.

I need help writing a breakup text to my boyfriend. We’ve been together 8 months, mostly long-distance, and I’ve realized our life goals and communication styles don’t match. He’s kind and hasn’t done anything “wrong,” but I don’t want to keep trying when it doesn’t feel right. I want to be clear, kind, and final—no false hope, no “maybe later,” and no promise to stay friends—but I want to respect him and thank him. Please include a line about returning his hoodie and keep it around 150–180 words. Use his name (Ethan) and sign it with mine (Maya).

My ex asked if we could “stay friends,” but I’m not ready and need space to heal. Can you give me 3 short text replies I can send: one gentle, one firmer, and one tailored for when we still have to interact at work? Also add two quick tips for setting boundaries and muting social media so I don’t keep reopening the wound.
